facts.text: Four civil appeals numbered 502 to 505 of 1960 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: C. As. Nos. 502 to 505 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and orders dated January 14, 1957 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1848 to 1851 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and orders dated January 14, 1957 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1848 to 1851 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and orders dated January 14, 1957 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Applications Nos. 1848 to 1851 of 1956. D. Karkhanis and P. D. Menon for the appellant  in all the four appeals . T. Desai and I. N. Shroff fur the Respondents.

facts.text: Respondents are four partners in firm Mafatlal Gagalbhai Sons: Navinchandra Mafatlal (5/16), Arvind N. Mafatlal (3/16), Yoginder N. Mafatlal (3/16), Homant Mafatlal (5/16).

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in these four appeals are each of the four partners in a firm companystituted under the name of Mafatlal Gagalbhai Sons and which was companyposed of Navinchandra Mafatlal, Arvind N. Mafatlal, Yoginder N.Mafatlal and Homant Mafatlal with shares of 5/16, 3/16, 3/16, and 5/16 respectively in that firm

facts.text: Navinchandra Mafatlal died subsequent to Bombay High Court decision; legal representatives brought on record in Civil Appeal No. 502 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be mentioned that Navinchandra died subsequent to the decision of the High Court and his legal representatives have been brought on record in Civil Appeal No. 502 of 1959 but this circumstance being irrelevant we are ignoring it for the purposes of these appeals

facts.text: Firm Mafatlal Gagalbhai Sons registered under Indian Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The firm was registered under the Indian Income Tax Act. There was a private limited companypany named Mafatlal Apte and Kantilal Limited registered under the Phaltan State Companies Act.

facts.text: Private limited company named Mafatlal Apte and Kantilal Limited registered under Phaltan State Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: There was a private limited companypany named Mafatlal Apte and Kantilal Limited registered under the Phaltan State Companies Act. Ton Shares in this private companypany stood in the name of Navin Chandra, 10 in the name of Arvind and 20 in the name of Ham ant.

facts.text: 40 shares in company: 10 in Navinchandra, 10 in Arvind, 20 in Homant.

anchor.surface_text: Ton Shares in this private companypany stood in the name of Navin Chandra, 10 in the name of Arvind and 20 in the name of Ham ant. For the account year of the companypany ending September 30, 1945 the companypany disclosed a net profit of Rs. 1,09,165/-

facts.text: Company account year ending September 30, 1945 disclosed net profit of Rs. 1,09,165; no dividend declared but paid income-tax and super-tax.

anchor.surface_text: For the account year of the companypany ending September 30, 1945 the companypany disclosed a net profit of Rs. 1,09,165/-. The companypany, however, did number declare any dividend out of those profits but paid income-tax and super-tax thereon.

facts.text: After merger of Phaltan State in Indian Union, Income Tax Officer issued notice under s.34 to company and under s.23A deemed Rs.68,228 undistributed income as dividend distributed on March 11, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: After the merger of the Phaltan State in the Indian Union and the ex. tension of the provisions of the Indian Income Tax Act thereto, the In companye Tax Officer who had jurisdiction over the assessment of the companypany, issued numberice to it under s. 34 of the Indian Income Tax Act and acting under the provisions of s. 23A thereof directed that the undistributed assessable income of the companypany which amounted to Rs. 68,228/- should be deemed to have been distributed as dividend among the shareholders as on the date of the General Body Meeting of the companypany  i.e., on March 11 1946 .

facts.text: Before s.23A order, assessments of firm Mafatlal Gagalbhai Sons and its four partners completed.

anchor.surface_text: Before the date of this order the assessment of the firm of Mafatlal Gaalbhai Sons and the individual assessment of its four partners had been companypleted In order to bring to tax the undistributed dividend deemed to be declared under s. 23A among the shareholders of the companypany numberices .were issued to the four partners under s. 31 of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer issued notices under s.31 to four partners for deemed dividend.

anchor.surface_text: In order to bring to tax the undistributed dividend deemed to be declared under s. 23A among the shareholders of the companypany numberices .were issued to the four partners under s. 31 of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Partners stated that 40 shares held by three partners were benami for the firm; Income Tax Officer accepted this contention.

anchor.surface_text: In respondent to the numberice the partners appeared and it was stated in their behalf that the 40 shares hold by three of the partners in .the companypany were in fact the property of the Registered firm and were held by them benami for the firm. This companytention was accepted by the Income Tax Officer

facts.text: Income Tax Officer treated dividend on 40 shares as firm's income and apportioned among four partners per their shares in firm.

anchor.surface_text: who thereupon treated the dividend attributable to the 40 shares as the dividend income of the, firm and proceeded to apportion the said income among the four partners in the proportion of the shares which each of them held in the firm and added this to the income already assessed,

facts.text: Income Tax Officer committed error by including only net dividend and allowing deduction of tax paid by company.

anchor.surface_text: In doing so however, the Income Tax Officer company- mitted an error. In recomputing the total income of each of these four assessees he included only the net dividend. to be received by each but as against this addition he allowed a deduction of the tax paid by the companypany attributable to such dividend.

facts.text: No appeals against these assessment orders; they became final.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberappeal against these assessment orders which became final.

facts.text: On April 13, 1954, Income Tax Officer issued notices under s.35 to four partners to rectify error of not grossing up net dividend.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently this mistake was discovered and thereupon the lncome-Tax officer-issued, numberices to the four partners on April 13, 1954 pointing out the error in including in the income the net dividend without being grossed up, while at the same time allowing credit for the tax deemed to have been paid thereon.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer by order dated October 12, 1955 rectified assessments by grossing up dividend income and retained relief under s.18(5).

anchor.surface_text: he Income Tax Officer by his order dated October 12, 1955 rectified the .assessment by grossing up the newly added dividend income by the addition of the tax deemed to have been paid by the companypany thereon and retained the original relief granted under B. 18  5  of the Act.

facts.text: Assessees unsuccessfully appealed rectification orders to higher authorities.

anchor.surface_text: After unsuccessfully appealing to the higher authorities for relief against this rectification the assessees filed writ petitions invoking the jurisdiction of the High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 of the companystitution

facts.text: Assessees filed writ petitions under Arts. 226 and 227 in Bombay High Court to prohibit enforcement of rectification orders dated October 12, 1955; petitions allowed.

anchor.surface_text: the assessees filed writ petitions invoking the jurisdiction of the High Court under Arts. 226 and 227 of the companystitution for prohibiting the authorities from taking proceedings for the enforcement of the orders dated October 12, 1955. The learned Judges allowed the petitions.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer obtained certificates under Art.133(1)(c) from High Court; appeals now before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer thereafter moved the High Court for certificates of fitness under Art. 133 1  c  and these having been granted the appeals are number before us.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held that since firm was shareholder, distribution to partners not deemed dividend under s.16(2).

anchor.surface_text: The ground upon which the learned Judge granted the relief to the respondents was briefly this The order of assessment had proceeded on the basis that the firm of Mafatlal Gagalbliai Sons was the shareholder who had been in receipt of the dividend-income and the individual partners of the firm had been made liable for their share of the profits derived from this registered firm.

facts.text: Yoginder N. Mafatlal had no shares in his name.

anchor.surface_text: We consider the submission of learned Counsel for the respondents that the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction under s. 35 to rectify errors but number to effect merely readjustments so as to avoid illogicalities in an error which is still permitted to companytinue is wellfounded.

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in Messrs. Howrah Trading Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax Calcutta  1  that it is only the registered shareholder who is entitled to the benefit of the credit for tax paid by the companypany under s. 18  5  as well as the companyresponding grossing up under s. 16 2 .

arguments.claim: Income Tax Officer committed error in treating registered firm as owner of all 40 shares for s.16(2) and s.18(5) benefits

anchor.surface_text: On that basis the only persons who were entitled to be treated as shareholders to whom the provisions of ss. 16 2  and 18 5  of the Income Tax Act were attracted were the three partners in whose names the 40 shares stood registered, as detailed earlier. An error had therefore been companymitted by the Income Tax Officer in treating the registered firm as the owner of the shares in respect of the entire number of 40 shares.

arguments.claim: s.35 allows rectification of errors but not mere readjustments to avoid illogicalities in a continuing error

anchor.surface_text: We companysider the submission of learned Counsel for the respondents that the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction under s. 35 to rectify errors but number to effect merely readjustments so as to avoid illogicalities in an error which is still permitted to companytinue is wellfounded.

arguments.court_reasoning: We consider the submission ... is wellfounded

arguments.claim: s.35 proceedings did not seek to rectify initial fundamental error but to carry it to logical conclusion and perpetuate it

anchor.surface_text: It was number this initial and fundamental error that was sought to be rectified by the proceedings under s. 35, but the removal of an anomaly in that error which companytinued to be affixed in other words the object of the proceedings under s. 35 was to carry out to its logical companyclusion the error which had been companymitted in the order of assessment dated October 12, 1955 passed after invoking the provisions of s. 34.

arguments.claim: Initial error cannot be corrected under s.35 as notice seeks perpetuation of error not correction

anchor.surface_text: It has further to be mentioned that it is number possible to companyrect the initial error in these proceedings because the numberice under s. 33 which is the foundation of the jurisdiction of the officer to effect the rectification, sought in reality number the companyrection of the error but the perpetuation of it though in an altered and less objectionable form from the point of view of Revenue

holdings.text: It is only the registered shareholder who is entitled to the benefit of the credit for tax paid by the company under s. 18(5) as well as the corresponding grossing up under s. 16(2).

anchor.surface_text: This Court has held in Messrs. Howrah Trading Co., Ltd. v. The Commissioner of Income-Tax Calcutta  1  that it is only the registered shareholder who is entitled to the benefit of the credit for tax paid by the companypany under s. 18  5  as well as the companyresponding grossing up under s. 16 2 . On that basis the only persons who were entitled to be treated as shareholders to whom the provisions of ss. 16 2  and 18 5  of the Income Tax Act were attracted were the three partners in whose names the 40 shares stood registered, as detailed earlier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly following binding precedent from this Court in Howrah Trading Co. Ltd. v. CIT.

holdings.text: The only persons entitled to be treated as shareholders for provisions of ss. 16(2) and 18(5) were the three partners in whose names the 40 shares stood registered.

anchor.surface_text: On that basis the only persons who were entitled to be treated as shareholders to whom the provisions of ss. 16 2  and 18 5  of the Income Tax Act were attracted were the three partners in whose names the 40 shares stood registered, as detailed earlier.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying the registered shareholder principle to the facts where shares were registered in names of three individual partners, not the firm.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer committed an error in treating the registered firm as the owner of the shares in respect of the entire 40 shares for ss. 16(2) and 18(5).

anchor.surface_text: An error had therefore been companymitted by the Income Tax Officer in treating the registered firm as the owner of the shares in respect of the entire number of 40 shares. It was number this initial and fundamental error that was sought to be rectified by the proceedings under s. 35, but the removal of an anomaly in that error which companytinued to be affixed in other words the object of the proceedings under s. 35 was to carry out to its logical companyclusion the error which had been companymitted in the order of assessment dated October 12, 1955 passed after invoking the provisions of s. 34.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical consequence of applying registered shareholder rule to undisputed registration of shares in individual partners' names despite benami claim accepted for income attribution.

holdings.text: The s.35 proceedings sought not to rectify the initial fundamental error but to carry out that error to its logical conclusion by removing an anomaly while the error continued.

anchor.surface_text: It was number this initial and fundamental error that was sought to be rectified by the proceedings under s. 35, but the removal of an anomaly in that error which companytinued to be affixed in other words the object of the proceedings under s. 35 was to carry out to its logical companyclusion the error which had been companymitted in the order of assessment dated October 12, 1955 passed after invoking the provisions of s. 34.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of purpose of s.35 notice and rectification order shows it addressed grossing-up anomaly without challenging the fundamental error of treating firm as shareholder.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction under s.35 to rectify errors but not to effect merely readjustments so as to avoid illogicalities in an error which is still permitted to continue.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider the submission of learned Counsel for the respondents that the Income Tax Officer had jurisdiction under s. 35 to rectify errors but number to effect merely readjustments so as to avoid illogicalities in an error which is still permitted to companytinue is wellfounded.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.35 limited to correcting apparent mistakes from record, not adjusting consequences of uncorrected fundamental errors; submission of respondents' counsel accepted as well-founded.

holdings.text: It is not possible to correct the initial error in s.35 proceedings because the notice, foundation of jurisdiction, sought perpetuation of the error in altered form, not correction.

anchor.surface_text: It has further to be mentioned that it is number possible to companyrect the initial error in these proceedings because the numberice under s. 33 which is the foundation of the jurisdiction of the officer to effect the rectification, sought in reality number the companyrection of the error but the perpetuation of it though in an altered and less objectionable form from the point of view of Revenue

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction under s.35 depends on notice; here notice perpetuated rather than corrected the core mistake, precluding rectification of initial error.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore companysider that the appeals must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of holdings on registered shareholder rule and limits of s.35 rectification justifies upholding High Court quashing of rectification orders.
